entry.title: A Great Kids Indoor Playground Near Metro Vancouver 2: HANABaby Adventure World

link.title: A Great Kids Indoor Playground Near Metro Vancouver 2: HANABaby Adventure World

entry.content:
🧸 Visiting HANABaby Adventure World

📍 Location: 2nd Floor, Royal City Centre Mall, 610 6th St #251, New Westminster, BC V3L 3C1
💰 Admission Fees:

  • Weekdays: $26.99 (1 child + 1 adult, unlimited playtime)
    Extra child $19.99 + GST / Extra adult $7 + GST
  • Weekends & Holidays (2 hours): $26.99 (1 child + 1 adult)
    Extra child $19.99 + GST / Extra adult $7 + GST
  • Weekends & Holidays (All-day pass): $32.99 (1 child + 1 adult)
    Extra child $25.99 + GST / Extra adult $7 + GST
  • 🍼 Infants under 1 year old enter free

📸 All photos have been edited with Photoshop’s magic tools to remove any visible people for privacy reasons.
For more lively, unedited pictures, check out the Google Maps reviews.

🗺️ Layout Overview


(This is a simple hand-drawn reference map — not perfectly to scale,
but it shows the layout from the Admission Desk at the entrance
to the active play zone, pretend play zone, rest area, and party room.)

As of 2025, the playground is divided into two main sections —
the left side for active play and the right side for pretend play.
Down the hallway, you’ll find the rest area, restroom, and party room.

🎠 Active Play Zone

The left section is where kids can burn off their energy.
It features a ball pit, slides, a small maze structure, and a trampoline at the very back.
Kids love climbing up and down the slides and maze repeatedly — perfect for tiring them out 😆


(Located near the trampoline area; another swing can be found behind the rainbow slide.)

Interestingly, there are two swings hanging under the maze,
and many kids end up staying there for surprisingly long stretches of time!

🍳 Pretend Play Zone


(Our kid’s favorite — the kitchen play zone!)

The right side is quieter, filled with role-play setups like
a kitchen, supermarket, doctor’s office, princess room, and fire station.

Some toys are missing or slightly worn out —
but the kitchen and supermarket areas are still in good condition,
and there’s a nice selection of dresses and costumes that keep kids entertained for a while.

☕ Rest Area & Party Room


(The hallway between the active and pretend play zones — follow it to reach the rest area.)

Down the hallway, there’s a rest area with a restroom and a birthday party room.
This part is both the strength and weakness of the playground.
There’s only one restroom, which can be inconvenient,
but outside food is allowed, making it a comfortable space for snacks or meals.
You’ll even see some parents working on their laptops here while their kids play nearby.

🚗 Parking & Nearby Food Options

Since HANABaby is located inside Royal City Centre Mall,
you get 3 hours of free parking.
If you purchase the all-day pass, you’ll need to pay for extra time after 3 hours.

Inside the mall, you’ll find A&W,
and just outside are McDonald’s, Save-On-Foods, and Walmart —
making it super easy to grab food or snacks to bring back to the rest area.

🧒 Overall Impression

Overall, HANABaby Adventure World is best suited for younger kids (ages 2–4)
and especially for girls, since the pretend play area takes up a large portion of the space.
It’s not huge, but considering there aren’t many similar indoor playgrounds
around New Westminster or Burnaby,
this one feels like a real gem on a rainy day ☔

📍 View on Google Maps
https://maps.app.goo.gl/phy7r1dsUcgD9zDK9

entry.title: 🎃 Burnaby Halloween Events Guide 2025
entry.content:
🎃 Burnaby Halloween Events Guide 2025

October is here — and that means Halloween fun all across Burnaby!
From family-friendly festivals to teen and community events,
here’s a complete list of Halloween happenings in Burnaby, organized by date.

🎫 Most events are free, but a few may require advance registration or small admission fees.

📅 Events by Date

Date Event Details & Links
Oct 6 – 31 Halloweeks @ The Amazing Brentwood A month-long Halloween celebration at Brentwood Mall — photo zones, trick-or-treat, story time, and a photo contest, all free to join. Official Site
Oct 10 – 31 Halloween Hunt @ The City of Lougheed A family scavenger hunt inside Lougheed Town Centre. Pick up a free Halloween Boo-k at Guest Services, complete the missions, and get a treat! Limited quantities. Event Info
Oct 12 Halloween Delight @ Metropolis at Metrotown Family fun at Metrotown Mall — pumpkin carving demo, kids’ activities, and photo ops. Learn More
Oct 18 – 19 Day of the Dead Festival A vibrant Latin-inspired celebration within Brentwood’s Halloweeks — music, dance, food, and culture. Details
Oct 22 – 27 Haunted Village @ Burnaby Village Museum Burnaby’s classic Halloween attraction with ghostly lights, live performers, and evening tours. 🎟️ Ticketed event – advance purchase required. Details
Oct 24 (Fri) Bonsor’s Big Boo @ Bonsor Recreation Complex Indoor family festival featuring games, face painting, costume contests, and photo booths. Event Info
Oct 25 (Sat) Central Spark Halloween Festival @ Central Park Burnaby’s biggest outdoor Halloween festival! Live music, food trucks, light displays, and kids’ activity booths. Free admission, no registration needed. More Info
Oct 26 (Sun) Ghouls & Goblins Public Skate @ Bill Copeland Sports Centre A spooky-themed public skate — come in costume and enjoy treats on ice! Event Info
Oct 26 (Sun) Halloween Howler @ Willingdon Community Centre Indoor kids’ carnival with crafts, games, and candy giveaways. More Info
Oct 28 (Tue) Teen Toonie Skate – Vampires & Zombies @ Kensington Complex A Halloween-themed skate night just for teens. Admission only $2 (Toonie). Costumes welcome! Event Info
Oct 29 (Wed) Trick-or-Treat Public Skate @ Kensington Complex Family-friendly skating session with candy stations around the rink. More Info
Oct 30 (Thu) Spooky Bash @ Edmonds Community Centre Evening community party with music, crafts, and games. Costumes encouraged! Event Info
Oct 31 (Fri – Halloween Day) Monster Mash @ Eileen Dailly Pool A fun pool party with music, games, and costume contests in the water! Details
Oct 31 (Fri) Spooky Tiny Tikes @ Cameron Recreation Complex A morning program just for little ones (ages 5 and under). Safe indoor fun with crafts and games. Event Info
Nov 1 (Sat) Pumpkin Parade @ Deer Lake Park Bring your carved pumpkins for Burnaby’s final Halloween send-off — an evening lantern parade around the park. More Info

🧡 Tips for Enjoying Halloween in Burnaby

  • 🎭 Dress up!
    Most events encourage costumes — it makes the experience way more fun (and your photos way cuter).

  • 🕓 Know which events need tickets.
    Haunted Village is the only one requiring paid advance tickets.
    Everything else is free and open to the public.

  • 🚗 Plan parking or take transit.
    Weekend crowds can be heavy; arriving early or using SkyTrain is recommended.

  • 📸 Bring your camera.
    Brentwood, Lougheed, and Metrotown malls go all-out with decorations — perfect for family photos!

🎃 Final Thoughts

Throughout October, Burnaby turns into a city-wide Halloween playground.
With so many malls, community centres, and parks joining the fun,
you can celebrate the spooky season without leaving town.

If you’re looking for family-friendly Halloween events this year,
Burnaby has everything you need — all in one city.

📍 Useful Links

  • City of Burnaby – Official Halloween Events Page
  • The Amazing Brentwood – Halloweeks
  • The City of Lougheed – Halloween Hunt
  • Metropolis at Metrotown – Halloween Delight

entry.title: A Great Kids Indoor Playground Near Metro Vancouver: Wonderland Kids Indoor Play Center

link.title: A Great Kids Indoor Playground Near Metro Vancouver: Wonderland Kids Indoor Play Center

entry.content:
🏰 Visit to Wonderland Kids Indoor Play Center

📍 Location: 328-4949 Canoe Pass Way, Tsawwassen, BC V4M 0B2
💰 Price: 1 Child + 1 Adult → $25.99 + GST
⏰ Playtime: Unlimited on weekdays, 2-hour limit on weekends

🎡 Layout Overview


(This is a simplified floor map I drew myself — not to scale.)

As of 2025, the play center is divided into three main zones:
1️⃣ Main Play Area (included with admission)
2️⃣ Add-on Zone 1: Rainbow Haven
3️⃣ Add-on Zone 2: Ninja Jump

The main play area alone is more than enough for most kids.
If it’s your first visit, there’s really no need to pay for the add-ons right away.
(Of course, the owner will recommend them — just smile and say, “Next time, thank you 😊.”)

🧩 Main Play Area (Maze)


(This photo was taken from the back of the main area. You can find more photos on Google Maps reviews.)

The centerpiece is a massive maze-like play structure filled with slides in every direction.
Each child finds their own favorite route through the tunnels and ramps.

Behind it, there’s a block-building zone and a small toddler-only area (for ages 3 and under).
The toddler zone isn’t very large, so it may not be worth visiting just for that age group —
but if you have siblings of different ages, it’s perfect for everyone to enjoy together.


(A quiet block-building area where kids can focus and play calmly.)

The facility has plenty of restrooms, and they’re kept very clean thanks to frequent staff checks.
There’s also a bouncy castle section, where kids can literally jump until they run out of energy 😆

🌈 Add-on Zone 1: Rainbow Haven

This zone features a web-like climbing structure made of soft netting —
something you might often see in Korean-style indoor playgrounds.
My kids weren’t too interested in it, but some children loved it so much
they stayed there almost the entire time.

🧗 Add-on Zone 2: Ninja Jump

This section includes trampolines, small climbing walls,
and various balance challenge courses — perfect for energetic kids.

Our children absolutely loved it and spent most of their time here,
burning off every bit of energy they had.

If your kids enjoy physical play, the add-on fee is totally worth it.
But since these zones aren’t included in the base ticket,
you can always explore first and decide later.

☕️ Café & Rest Area


(The kids in this photo have been removed with a photo tool, so you might notice some smudges.)

Food and drinks are only allowed in the designated dining area outside the play zone.
Non-playing adults can also sit there to relax and keep an eye on the kids.

Outside food is allowed, and there are plenty of options nearby —
A&W, Firehouse Subs, and Starbucks are all within walking distance.
One parent can even pop over to Tsawwassen Mills to grab snacks or meals.
No worries — there’s no shortage of food around here!

🧒🏻 Overall Impression

Although FlyO’Land Kids’ Playcenter inside Tsawwassen Mills is more well-known,
I personally preferred Wonderland Kids Indoor Play Center.

It’s especially great for kids who love running and climbing.
The maze is big and open enough that parents can join in easily —
which isn’t always the case in many other indoor playgrounds.

Because it’s spacious, the air circulation feels much better too.

I’d honestly call this one of the best indoor playgrounds in the Greater Vancouver area
entry.summary: 🏰 Visit to Wonderland Kids Indoor Play Center
